verses.verse: When morning arrived, all the chief priests and elders of the people took counsel against Jesus to kill him.
When they had tied him up, they led him away and handed him over to Pontius Pilate, the governor.
Then Judas, who had betrayed him, after seeing he was condemned, regretted it, and returned the thirty pieces of silver to the chief priests and elders,
saying, "I have sinned in that I betrayed innocent blood." They replied, "What is it to us? That's your problem."
He threw the pieces of silver down in the Temple, left, and went and hung himself.
The chief priest took the silver pieces and said, "It is not lawful to put them into the treasure, because it is the price of blood."
So they took counsel and bought the potter's field with them to bury strangers.
Therefore that field was called "The Field of Blood" to this day.
That which was spoken of by Jeremiah the prophet was then fulfilled, "And they took the thirty pieces of silver, the price of his value, whom the Children of Israel did value.
«They gave them for the Potter's field as the Lord appointed me."
Jesus stood before the governor, and the governor asked him, saying, "Are you the King of the Jews?" And Jesus said to him, "You speck [the truth]."
When he was accused by the chief priests and elders, he didn't answer.
Then Pilate said to him, "Don't you hear how many things they witness against you?"
And he never answered him a word; insomuch that the governor was greatly amazed.
Now at the feast the governor was in the habit of releasing to the people a prisoner whom they wanted.
They had an infamous prisoner named Barabbas.
Therefore when they were gathered together Pilate said to them, "Whom do you want for me to release to you, Barabbas or Jesus who is called Christ?"
For he knew full well that because of envy they had handed him over.
When he had sat down on the judgment seat, his wife sent to him, saying, "Don't have nothing to do with that just man, for I have suffered many things this day in a dream because of him."
But the chief priests and elders persuaded the multitude that they should ask for Barabbas and kill Jesus.
The governor answered and said to them, "Which of the two do you want me to release to you?" They said, "Barabbas."
Pilate said to them, "What will I then do with Jesus who is called Christ?" All said to him, "Let him be crucified."
The governor said, "Why, what evil has he done?" But they shouted out even more, saying, "Let him be crucified."

When Pilate saw that he wasn't getting anywhere, but that a riot was starting, he took water and washed his hands before the multitude saying, "I am innocent of the blood of this just person. Now it is your problem."
All the people then answered and said, "His blood be on us and on our children."
Then he released Barabbas to them, and after having Jesus whipped, he handed him over to be crucified.
Then the governor's soldiers took Jesus into the common hall and gathered the whole squad of soldiers to him.
They stripped him and put a scarlet robe on him.
After braiding a crown of thorns, they put it on his head and a reed in his right hand, then they bowed the knee before him and made fun of him saying, "Hail, King of the Jews!"
They spit on him; they took a reed and hit him on the head.
After they had made fun of him, they took the robe off him and put on his own clothes and led him away to crucify him.
As they came out they found a man of Cyrene, named Simon; they compelled him to carry his cross.
When they came into a place called Golgotha, that is to say, "A Place of a Skull."
They gave him vinegar to drink mingled with gall, and when he had tasted it, he would not drink.
They crucified him and divided up his clothes, throwing lots, that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the prophet, "They divided up my clothes among them, and they threw lots on my clothing."
Sitting down, they watched him there.
They set up [a sign] over his head of his accusation, written, "This is Jesus, the King of the Jews."
At that time two thieves were crucified with him, one on the right hand and another on the left.
Those who passed by reviled him, shaking their heads.
And they were saying, "You who destroys the Temple and rebuilds it in three days, save yourself. If you are the Son of God, come down from the cross."
Likewise the chief priests also mocking him along with the scribes and elders said,
"He saved others; he cannot save himself. If he is the King of Israel, let him now come down from the cross, and we will believe him.
"He trusted in God; let him deliver him now, if he will have him, for he said, «I am the Son of God.'"
The thieves who were crucified with him also taunted him.
Now from the sixth hour there was darkness over all the land up to the ninth hour.
About the ninth hour Jesus shouted with a loud voice, saying, "Eli, Eli, lame sabachthani."
Some of those who stood there, when they heard that said, "This man calls for Elijah."
Immediately one of them ran, took a sponge, filled it with vinegar, put it on a stick, and gave him a drink.
The rest said, "Let it be, let us see if Elijah will come to save him."
Jesus after he had shouted again with a loud voice, yielded up his spirit.
Then look! The veil of the Temple was torn in two from the top to the bottom, the earth shook, and the rocks broke.
The graves were opened and many bodies of the saints, which slept, arose.
They came out of the graves after his resurrection, went into the Holy City, and appeared to many.
Now when the centurion and those with him guarding Jesus saw the earthquake and the things that happened, greatly feared, saying, "Truly, this was the Son of God."
Many women who had followed Jesus from Galilee ministering to him were there watching from afar.
Among them were Mary Magdalene and Mary, the mother of James and Joseph, and the mother of Zebedee's children.
When evening came, a rich man from Arimathaea, named Joseph, came there; he was also a disciple of Jesus.
He went to Pilate and begged for the body of Jesus. Then Pilate commanded the body to be given up.
After Joseph had taken the body, he wrapped it in a clean, linen cloth,
and laid it in his own tomb, which he had cut out in the rock, rolled a great stone to the door of the tomb, and left.
Mary Magdalene and the other Mary were sitting there in front of the tomb.
Now the next day following the Day of Preparation, the chief priests and Pharisees came together to Pilate.
They said, "Sir, we remember that the deceiver said, while he was alive, "After three days, I will rise again."

"Therefore give an order that the tomb be made secure until the third day, lest his disciples come by night and take him away, and then say to the people, "He is risen from the dead," so the last fraud will be worse than the first."
Pilate said to them, "You have a guard; go away; make it as secure as you can."
So they went and made the tomb secure, sealing the stone and setting the guard.
